body:
Comment 3: 
I think the main thing that is missing is a document explaining how to interpret the
all.bash output. 

Even if we were going to arrange for these command lines to be printed on every failure,
the crash you reported in comment #2 (at least judging from the part you included) looks
like it is the test runner that has crashed, not any specific test. The sad fact of
self-hosted systems like ours is that if you break the runtime or the compiler there's
very little stable left to stand on. Assuming it is the test runner that has failed, you
would not have gotten a useful command line even if we were trying to print them.

One possibility is that if this is an ongoing problem you could add 'set -x' to the top
of your src/run.bash.
